greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of ways to write prime(n) = a^2 + b^4.
comment: Conjecture: a(n) <= 2, empirically checked for the first 10^6 primes.

The conjecture is true, because by the uniqueness part of Fermat's two-squares theorem, at most one duplicate of a^2 + b^4 can exist. Namely, if a is a square, say a = B^2, then a^2 + b^4 = A^2 + B^4 where A = b^2. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Oct 03 2015
Friedlander and Iwaniec proved that a(n) > 0 infinitely often. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Oct 05 2015
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Art of Problem Solving, Fermat's Two Squares Theorem
John Friedlander and Henryk Iwaniec, Using a parity-sensitive sieve to count prime values of a polynomial, PNAS, vol. 94 no. 4, pp. 1054-1058.
example: First numbers n, such that a(n) > 0:
program: a256852_list = f a000040_list [] $ tail a000583_list where
| otherwise = (sum $ map (a010052 . (p -)) us) : f ps us vs'
results.author: _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Apr 11 2015
